utterances: The Nenets autonomous region lies far above the Arctic Circle and for about nine months of the year, it's blanketed in snow.
During the brief summer, a thin layer of grounds above the permafrost melts, exposing a vast flat expanse of marshy sand and scrub and unleashing vicious swarms of mosquitoes.
(SOUNDBITE OF BOAT IN WATER)
The regional capital Naryan-Mar, a dusty outpost of simple two-story buildings, stands on the Pechora River.
There is no permanent road connecting the town to the rest of Russia.
It's here that the Kremlin is waging the latest battle in its bid to make Russia an international energy superpower.
But the people of Naryan-Mar are pushing back.
Earlier this month, about 200 locals assembled in the main square to protest the arrest of their governor.
Authorities jailed Alexei Barinov last month on charges of fraud and embezzlement in a previous job.
(Speaking in foreign language)

Addressing the crowd, regional legislator Nikolai Fomin said the Kremlin's move was part of a carefully planned scheme to dismantle the local government and take control over the region's key resource.
Fomin says the Kremlin targeted the Nenets region because it had some of Russia's biggest untapped oil and gas reserves, which are still just being explored.
(Through translator) A signal has been sent to all governors using our example, that if you don't play by the rules we invented, the same fate awaits you.
Barinov's arrest came after a rare show of defiance to the Kremlin by the region's local legislators.
The governor refused to keep the representatives in line and the next day found himself the target of a criminal case.
He dismissed the charges as politically motivated.
(Through translator) People who are doing this have interests in the region that don't correspond to the interests of the region or the government.
So they began to dig for dirt on me.
Barinov was arrested the following day, then fired.
He's now awaiting trial.
Nenets residents were incensed.
They praised Barinov for standing up for them.
He opposed Moscow's plan to merge Nenets with the much poorer neighboring region Arkhangelsk.
They say the tough former oil men also forced oil companies in the region to pay taxes and finance projects such as building schools and libraries.
Retired kindergarten teacher Liudmilla Barabanova believes the Kremlin doesn't want locals to benefit from their region's oil well.
(Through translator) I think it's an outrage.
How can we live on this land where oil is being pumped out and get nothing?
The people of Nenets should benefit from it.
Analysts say Barinov's main mistake was running afoul of the burgeoning state Rosneft oil company, which is at the center at the Kremlin's plan to consolidate the country's energy industry.
Rosneft recently began expanding operations in Nenets, and Barinov had insisted the company pay more than $30 million it owes in back taxes.
Local administrator, Boris Dulniev, is a member of the pro-Kremlin United Russia Party.
He says rumors circulated that the Kremlin would try to smear Barinov.
(Through translator) But absolutely no one expected that it would be done openly, so crudely, so forcefully and so completely.
(Singing in Spanish)
Last year, more than 8,000 people were jailed in Spain for trafficking in cocaine.
Law enforcement officials say the country has also become a key European money laundering center for Columbian cocaine cartels.
Back in the arrivals lounge, Sergeant Jose Luis Queija scans the room with his deep-set eyes.
Queija heads the airport anti-narcotics squad for the Guardia Civil, Spain's paramilitary police force.
He's fought the elicit drugs trade long enough to be jaded.
(Spanish spoken)
In almost 30 years, I've seen it all, he says.
We've caught people with drugs in wheelchairs, bicycles, inside their bodies, in dogs, in animal cages, in tropical fruits, even in carnation stems.
Queija keeps a collection that includes a bowling ball, a bottle of shaving cream, statuettes, liquor bottles, you name it.
He used to be impressed by the traffickers' ingenuity.
(Spanish spoken)
But lately, I have to say, that sense of ingenuity is being lost because now there's just loads of it coming.
Sometimes they don't even bother to make hidden compartments, he says.
Already this year, police at Madrid's airport have seized more than two and a half tons of cocaine.
That's about as much as in all of last year.
Spain as a whole already accounts for about half of the more than 70 tons of cocaine seized yearly across the European Union.
Queija says Spain is a natural European gateway because of its cultural ties to Latin America.
But increasing crackdowns are forcing smugglers to diversify their routes, he says.
(Spanish spoken)
What's really hot now is West Africa, Cape Verde, Senegal, and that area.
You get containers of drugs unloaded there and it's brought to Europe, he says.
By transferring the drugs onto smaller boats, the traffickers can skirt the patrols along the lengthy coastlines of Northwest African and the Iberian Peninsula.
European law enforcement officials suspect that cocaine rings are working with smugglers of hashish on the Moroccan Coast.
They use powerboats to zip across the Strait of Gibraltar into Spain, where cocaine can earn the smuggler big bucks.
And it's also been fueling the party scene in beach resorts like Ibiza and in cities like Madrid.
(Soundbite of crowd)
It's 9:00 a.m. on a Sunday morning and many of those dancing at this after-hours club in Madrid have not slept since Friday.
And that's thanks to cocaine.
Here in the gym of the San Juan de Dios clinic in Madrid, a patient gets out his nervous energy on a punching bag.
Santiago is a 29-year-old psychology Ph.D. student.
He doesn't want his last name made public because he still hopes to salvage his career.
After getting excellent grades and using cocaine only at clubs on the weekends, Santiago tried crack one afternoon several years ago.
(Spanish spoken)
I look like the ideal kid, the perfect student.
I went out and nobody suspected anything, but I was smoking crack every afternoon in a ghetto with North African immigrants, he says.
Santiago's parents grew up during the Franco dictatorship.
Many in their generation are at a loss as to how to prevent their kids from trying drugs, especially, he says, when it's the thing to do.
(Spanish spoken)
It's a form of consumption that's accepted by society.
We see it in the media.
Just like musicians in the United States use it, in Spain too we see how they go in and out of detox apparently without problems.
And they are adored by the media, he says.
Spain is often called the California of Europe.
Compared to Calvinist Northern Europe, what counts here is appearances, says Javier, a 45-year-old court lawyer who's also undergoing treatment here.
(Spanish spoken)
You have to have a nice suit, a nice car, a nice watch and all of that, and your little bag of coke, he says.
Javier says revealing his surname would ruin his career.
His colleagues think he's in treatment for depression.
At the office, he used to get cocaine delivered by a fake client.
(Spanish spoken)
Mr.
So and So is here to see you, my secretary would say.
And I would answer, oh, yes, by all means, let him in.
He was the pusher.
He brought me the drugs, Javier says.
The therapy here at the San Juan de Dios clinic relies a lot on pure support and self-confrontation.
Santiago walks over to the full-length mirror in the gym.
(Spanish spoken)
It's very hard to stand in front of the mirror and look yourself in the eye and say things as they are.
I'm a drug addict and I want to get out of drugs, he says.
(Spanish spoken)
It certainly won't be easy.
He's here for the second time.
And doctors at this clinic say that's not unusual.
The success rate in overcoming addiction is 30 percent.
So far, Spain and Britain and a few other countries account for most of the spike in cocaine use in Europe.
But experts worry that with the cheap availability of the drug and the new trafficking routes, the problem could soon get much worse.
For NPR News, I'm Jerome Socolovsky in Madrid.
So we follow the drug trade forward from South America to West Africa to Europe.
You can trace those stories backward again if you like at npr.org.
One year ago today, Army Captain Douglas DiCenzo was killed by a roadside bomb in Baghdad.
He is one of more than 3,400 U.S.
military personnel who have died in the Iraq war.
His family is one of the thousands dealing with the lasting grief of their loss.
